coredata.dc:title: Building of sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure to circumvent the scaling relations in N2-to-NH3 electrocatalysis
coredata.dc:creator: Wu, Wenzhuo
Niu, Chunyao
Yan, Pengfei
Shi, Feng
Ma, Chunyan
Yang, Xinan
Jia, Yu
Chen, Jun
Ahmed, Muhammad Ibrar
Zhao, Chuan
Xu, Qun
coredata.dc:description: Finding catalysts and mechanisms for efficient electroreduction of N2 into NH3 remains of great challenge, due to the limitation of the scaling relations and competing HER. Here we report that N2 can be dissociated and dynamically hydrogenized on a peculiar sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure. Different with conventional surface-binding paradigms of the reaction intermediates, such a dynamic surface-binding paradigm can selectively stabilize the nitrogen intermediates and enable the circumvention of the inherent scaling relations in electrocatalysis of N2 to NH3. Atomic resolution AC-STEM and DFT calculations confirm the atomic arrangement and a ∼3% compressive strain in the large area of in-plane S-vacancies of sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure. Further experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the as-designed surface tune their catalytic properties through adjusting their surface-binding to nitrogen intermediates with tunable nitrogen affinity, leading to outstanding electrocatalytic NRR performance at ultra-low overpotential (−0.2 V. vs. RHE).

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Atomic resolution AC-STEM characterization of as-designed SM-MoS2-x (a–d). (a) AC-STEM image of the as-designed sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure, inset: the corresponding FFT pattern of (a). (b) AC-STEM intensity profiles along the corresponding dashed lines in (a). (c) Atomic model from geometry optimized DFT of the sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure. (d) AC-STEM image of few layer MoS2 with sub-monolayer MoS2-x structures. (e) EPR spectra of ultra-sonic exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet and as-used SM-MoS2-x.

DFT calculations of sub-monolayer MoS2-x. DFT model of (a) pristine MoS2, (b) Mo (110) and (c) sub-monolayer MoS2-x. Diagram of (d) electron local function (ELF, a value close to 0 indicates ionic bond dominance, a value close to 0.5 indicates metallic bond dominance, and a value close to 1 indicates covalent bond dominance) and (e) differential charge density (DCD) of sub-monolayer MoS2. (f) The selected region in (e).
(a) X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern for the as-prepared SM-MoS2-x nanosheets. (b) Raman Spectrum of SM-MoS2-x. (c) XPS spectra of Mo 3d.

Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction performance. (a) I-t plots obtained from the NRR at different overpotentials. (b) UV–vis spectra of electrolytes stained with indophenol indicator at different experimental conditions. (c) NH3 yield and (d) Faradaic efficiency at different overpotentials. 1H NMR spectra of the resultant electrolyte fed with 15N2 (e) and 14N2 (f).

(a) Free energy diagram for the electrochemical reduction of nitrogen on the SM-MoS2-x catalyst. The see-saw shows the energy barriers change of the dynamic N adsorption paradigm to break the scaling relations by using a strong N-affinity center (3 Mo atoms with “side on” adsorption of dinitrogen) for *N2 activation and a moderate N-affinity center (1 Mo atom with 1 N “end on” adsorption) to destabilize *NHz binding in SM-MoS2-x. (b) Free energy diagram of NRR and competing HER on SM-MoS2-x.

head.ce:title: Building of sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure to circumvent the scaling relations in N2-to-NH3 electrocatalysis

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Finding catalysts and mechanisms for efficient electroreduction of N2 into NH3 remains of great challenge, due to the limitation of the scaling relations and competing HER. Here we report that N2 can be dissociated and dynamically hydrogenized on a peculiar sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure. Different with conventional surface-binding paradigms of the reaction intermediates, such a dynamic surface-binding paradigm can selectively stabilize the nitrogen intermediates and enable the circumvention of the inherent scaling relations in electrocatalysis of N2 to NH3. Atomic resolution AC-STEM and DFT calculations confirm the atomic arrangement and a ∼3% compressive strain in the large area of in-plane S-vacancies of sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure. Further experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the as-designed surface tune their catalytic properties through adjusting their surface-binding to nitrogen intermediates with tunable nitrogen affinity, leading to outstanding electrocatalytic NRR performance at ultra-low overpotential (−0.2 V. vs. RHE).

ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) at ambient conditions using renewable energy has been the subject of intense research, which can alleviate the reliance on fossil fuels and CO2 emission in the conventional ammonia synthesis by the Haber-Bosch process [1–4]. To date, principles including nitrogenase, conventional heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis systems have been incorporated into the design of NRR electrocatalysts [5–7], and various NRR catalysts based on metallic elements and non-metallic elements have been developed [8–13]. Up to now, the major challenges are as following: (1) the adsorption and activation of the extremely inert N2 molecule; (2) the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and (3) the high overall energy barrier of this complicated six-electron-six-proton transfering process (N2 + 6H+ + 6e− = 2NH3) [6,14,15]. NRR electroatalysts ought to possess relatively strong nitrogen affinity to activate the non-polarizable N2 molecules, however, based on the adsorption-energy linear scaling relationships between the reaction intermediates (scaling relations), high nitrogen affinity would also stabilize the Nx (1 or 2)Hy (1–6) species and increase the energy barrier for ammonia release [16,17]. So the potentials for e-NRR are always negative, at which the side-reaction of HER are more competitive [15,18,19]. Therefore, finding efficient catalysts and mechanisms to circumvent the scaling relations is of vital importance to enable the both high catalytic activity and selectivity in e-NRR.

Selective stabilization of the adsorbates of Nx (1 or 2)Hy (0–6) species is the key to circumvent the scaling relations in electrocatalysis of NRR [16,17,20]. In fact, plenty of strategies such as strain engineering [16], plasma activation [17], electride support [21], single-cluster design [22,23], and dual-active sites [3,24,25] have been employed to break the scaling relations in conventional NRR catalysis. Moreover, inspired by nitrogenases, the metal-complex centres including bimetallic [26], trimetallic [22,27] and other [23,28] catalytic systems have also been constructed and proved capable of reducing N2 under mild conditions [29]. Notably, anion vacancies and low-coordinate metals (such as MoⅢ and FeⅡ. etc) with multi-step redox capacity are invariably significant structures for the active centres [5,22,30–32]. As an extensively studied 2D material, MoS2 has proven excellent hydrogenation performance in several important industrial reactions [33,34]. Although pristine MoS2 is of low-activity in e-NRR catalysis due to the overlap of p orbitals of S to d orbitals of Mo, fortunately, its potential catalytic activity for e-NRR have been proved by introducing exposed Mo edges (with low oxidization state) or doping [35–38]. Interestingly, the arrangement of Mo atoms in MoS2 is approximate to that of molydenum (110), which is one of the most active surfaces for nitrogen activiation, while it can not facilitate efficient proton transfer for e-NRR because the competition of HER [18,39]. Therefore, exploring a peculiar structure that can manifest the metallic properties of MoS2, and simultaneously can contribute to the proton-coupled electron-transfer (PCET) and as well as the dynamic nitrogen intermediates adsorption, is very necessary.

Herein, we develop a peculiar sub-monolayer MoS2 structure (SM-MoS2-x), accurately, islands of S atoms have been excluded from the sandwich structure of MoS2. The low-coordinate Mo ions (Moᵟ +, δ < 4, d Mo-Mo = 3.03 Å) and the arising compressive strain effect enable efficient N2 activation and dynamic nitrogen intermediates adsorption, due to high geometric and electronic flexibility of the resultant multi-nuclear active surface [22]. Besides, the relatively strong H-adsorbing ability of the active two-dimensional surface facilitates the adsorbed H to participate in the in-situ PCET for nitrogen reduction other than HER [40,41]. For the as-prepared sample with optimal sub-monolayer structure, the molecular adjustable surface exhibits an ammonia (NH3) yield (η) of 17.2 μg h−1·mgcata −1 and Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 24.7 % at a low overpotential of −0.2 V vs. RHE. Importantly, computational investigations indicate that the dynamic bonding of nitrogen intermediates to the special sub-surface enables the biomimetic “side-on” activation of dinitrogen and break the scaling relations, the easy migration of *NH3 over the sub-monolayer region further reduce the overall NRR energy barrier.

The synthesis of SM-MoS2-x was performed via a solid-solid reaction using NaBH4 as reductant [42,43]. NaBH4 crystal was firstly carefully ground into powder, and then was sufficiently mixed with MoS2 powders via grinding. After being degassed at 60 °C for 30 min under nitrogen (60 mL/min), the mixture was heated to 350 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The resultant mixture was cooled to the room temperature and added into 4 M HCl with vigorously magnetic stirring for 30 min. The sediment was separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water for 5 times. The resulted sediment deposits were dispersed in ethanol/water (v/v 1/1) mixtures and sonicated in the sonication bath for 0.5 h. Then the dispersion was centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 30 min to remove aggregates. The SM-MoS2-x in the supernatant was washed 3 times by high-speed (10,000 rpm for 30 min) centrifugation and drying in a vacuum oven.

The aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM) and STEM images of samples were measured with JEOL JEM-ARM300F. The elemental mapping images were taken using FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN operating at 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku D/Max 2550. X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Raman analysis was carried out on an inVia Raman spectrometer (Renishaw, UK) with 532 nm wavelength incident laser light. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an XPS, ESCA Lab250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with Al Kα source. All XPS spectra were corrected using the C1s line at 284.6 eV, and curve fitting and background subtraction were accomplished. EPR spectra were obtained using a Bruker EMX plus-9.5/12/P/L electron spin resonance spectrometer at 298 K.

All electrochemical evaluations were conducted in a gas-tight, three-electrode H-type electrochemical cell, with the cathodic chamber and the anodic chamber being separated by a proton exchange membrane (Nafion 211). Nafion membrane (Nafion 211) was first protonated by boiling in deionized water for 1 h, then in H2O2 for 1 h, and subsequently in deionized water for another 1 h, followed by 2 h in 0.5 M H2SO4, and finally for 5 h in deionized water. Platinum wire and Ag/AgCl (sat. KCl) was used as counter electrode (CE) and reference electrode (RE), respectively. The NRR working electrodes were prepared by a drop-casting method onto carbon fiber paper (CFP). 2 mg of the prepared electrocatalyst and 0.1 wt% of Nafion were dispersed in 1 ml of ethanol/water (v/v 1/1) solution uniformly by ultrasonication for 30 min. Subsequently, the homogeneously dispersed ink was drop-casted to the CFP electrode to achieve a catalyst loading of ∼0.25 mg cm−2. LSV characterizations of the catalyst were carried out at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in both N2 and Ar saturated 0.05 M H2SO4 electrolyte (gas purging rate = 20 mL min−1). The uniform volume of electrolyte used in this research is 50 mL. Before the measurements, the as-used N2 (purity: 99.999 %) and Ar (purity: 99.999 %) gases were washed with 0.05 M H2SO4 and deionized water. Besides, the electrolyte was degassed with the foregoing washed high-purity N2 or Ar for 30 min (flow rate: 30 mL min−1). Moreover, all electrochemical NRR performance tests were carried out with continuous gas purging constant bubbling outlet position which is close to the working cathode. All the potentials applied were converted to RHE according to the following equation:
E RHE = E (Ag/AgCl) + 0.197 + 0.059*pH

All the calculations are based on Density Functional Theory (DFT) as implemented in the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) codeutilizing the projector augmented wave method (PAW) [44,45]. The exchange-correlation energy of generalized gradient approximation put forward by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) [46] is adopted, and the vdW interaction is treated using the DFT-D3 method proposed by Grimme [47]. A vacuum of 15 Å perpendiculars to the sheets was applied to avoid the interaction between layers. A kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV is used for the plane-wave basis set. Because the supercell that we used is large, so only the Gama point is employed to sample the Brillouin-zone. Convergence criteria employed for both the electronic self-consistent relaxation and ionic relaxation are set to be 10−4 and 0.02 eV/Å for energy and force, respectively.

The SM-MoS2-x system is constructed with a 8*8*1 supercell containing about 30 % S vacancies according to our experimental findings. The O atoms are adsorbed at the edge S vacancies sites as shown in Fig. S21b. All the S vacancies are only formed on the surface (top side of the monolayer) and form a single stretch. The %S-vacancy being defined as (number of S vacancies)/(number of total S atoms at top side).

The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for each step of the NRR was calculated as follows:
(1) ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS (T = 298.15 K)
where ΔE, ΔZPE, and ΔS are the changes in the reaction energy, zero-point energy, and entropy, respectively.

The zero-point energy and entropy correction were obtained from the NIST-JANAF thermodynamics table for gas molecules, and by calculating the vibrational frequencies for the intermediate adsorbates, respectively [48].

To enhance the catalytic activity of MoS2, the rational modulation of the atomic and electronic structures is of vital importance. Here six recognized methods applied for the description of as-prepared SM-MoS2-x samples are presented: (1) direct observation from AC-STEM images; (2) computational simulation; (3) XRD characterization; (4) Raman test; (5) XPS characterization and (6) EPR measurements.

The atomic configuration of the sub-monolayer structure of MoS2-x (SM-MoS2-x) is confirmed using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM). Fig. 1 a shows a wide-field of view of the SM-MoS2-x basal plane, the atom arrangement in which accords well with the characteristic hexagonal pattern of 2H-MoS2 [49]. Intensity profile analysis of the AC-STEM image obtained from the indicated lines (Fig. 1b) demonstrates the formation of S vacancies with high stiochiometric ratio [31]. A model distribution of large area of S vacancies is simulated in Fig. 1c, showing a peculiar nanoscale size of sub-monolayer MoS2-x region. A sub-monolayer structure in the as-prepared few layer MoS2 catalysts is presented in the AC-STEM image of Fig. 1d. Furthermore, EPR characterization is utilized to verify the existence of S vacancies in SM-MoS2-x. It can be seen that the sub-monolayer MoS2-x display significantly intensified and broadened signal at g = 2.003, but no visible signal is observed on pristine MoS2 nanosheets (Fig. 1e) [31].

Interestingly, because of the high reducibility of NaBH4 and the exothermic character of the solid reaction, various peculiar structures involving grain boundary (highlighted by the translucent white box), layer edges (light dash line), 3R phase, and basal plane S vacancies are obtained (Fig. S2a) [49]. The corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern of the inset picture in Fig. S2a demonstrates the crystal structure of few layer MoS2 [50]. Moreover, the generated S vacancies on basal planes tend to be continuous configurations in nanoscale and close to the grain boundary (Fig. S2b) and layer edge (Fig. S2e) [49,50]. To clarify the structure of S vacancies in the few layer region, a side-view simulated configuration is displayed in Fig. S2c, and the boxed line profiles (Fig. S2d and S2f) of J 1 in Fig. S2c and J 2 in Fig. S2e, remarkably indicate the loss of S atoms (see further discussion in Fig. S3) [49]. According to the measurement in Fig. S2f, the bond length between neighboring Mo atoms in the S loss region is slightly reduced from a value of 3.13 Å in the pristine lattice to 3.03 Å (labeled by dpristine and d1S respectively) [50].

Moreover, the effect of large-area S vacancies on the geometric and electronic structure of the as-prepared sub-monolayer MoS2 were investigated through DFT simulation calculations. As shown in Fig. 2 a and b, the distances between Mo-Mo atoms in MoS2 (001) facet and Mo (110) facet are ∼3.17 Å and ∼2.72 Å, respectively. Interestingly, by introducing large-area of S vacancies in MoS2, the distance between the exposed Mo atoms in the vacancy region decrease obviously (Fig. 2c). The average Mo-Mo distance in the vacancy regions is reduced about ∼0.1 Å compared with that in MoS2 (001), which corresponds well with the experimental results in Fig. S3b. Besides, the effect of geometric structure on the electronic structure, has also been proved. As shown in Fig. 2d, the Mo-Mo electrons in the S vacancy are significantly more metallic than in the lattice perfection region (Fig. 2e) [51]. The simulation results indicate that the introduction of large-area S vacancies can help to break the overlap of p orbitals of S to the 3d orbital of Mo in MoS2 (Fig. 2f) [52]. Notably, the Mo-Mo electronic states in the S vacancy region reach the value between semiconductor (pristine MoS2) and Mo metal, and thus resultant peculiar geometric and electronic structure is of great potential in catalysis.

Fig. 3 a shows the XRD spectra of the as-prepared SM-MoS2-x, in which the diffraction peaks at 14.6 and 58.4° can be indexed to (002) and (110) planes of the 2H-MoS2 crystal phase (JCPDS card no. 37-1492) [31]. Moreover, the Raman Spectrum (Fig. 3b) shows that the treated sample exhibited the doublet at around 378 and 403 cm−1, which is attributable to characteristic E1 2g and A1g modes of 2H-MoS2 bands, respectively. Besides, peaks at 283, 665, 819 and 992 cm−1 are all assigned to MoO3 [42,43], indicating the partially oxidation on the surface of the sample, which are in accordance with the results in elemental mapping (Fig. S2g–i). Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is carried out to analyze the chemical composition and oxidation states of the elements in the as- prepared SM-MoS2-x (Figs. 3c, S5). The Mo 3d scan in Fig. 3c reveals Mo4+ peaks at 232.6 eV (3d3/2) and 229.1 eV (3d5/2), and Moδ+ (δ < 4) peaks at 231.5 (3d3/2) and 228.1 eV (3d5/2), which can be associated with low-coordinate Mo atoms close to S vacancies in 2H-MoS2 [41,43]. Now it is recognized that the integral area of Moδ+ (δ < 4) corresponds to the concentration of S vacancies (Fig. S6) and these low-coordinate Mo atoms play an important role in the step of proton adsorption [41].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performance of N2 electroreduction to ammonia on SM-MoS2-x
ce:section.ce:para: Initially, we evaluate the catalytic NRR performance of the SM-MoS2-x electrocatalyst by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) [41]. After saturating the electrolyte with N2 to replace the Ar, a slight shift to the lower potential in the LSV curves of the SM-MoS2-x samples is observed (Figs. S10a, S13), indicating the potential for NRR [9]. Furthermore, I-t curves in Fig. 4 a record the current responses with potentials ranging from −0.5 to −0.1 V vs. RHE and exert good stability. Meanwhile, to confirm the generation of the ammonia and possible by-product hydrazine, electrolytes after 2 h electrolysis operation are detected by the indophenol blue and Watt method [41], respectively. Fig. 4b shows the UV–vis absorption spectra of electrolytes colored with indophenol indicator, indicating the unambiguous formation of NH3 at different potentials. Notably, under the optimal potential of −0.2 V vs. RHE, the coresponding UV–vis absorption spectrum displays the highest absorbance intensity, implying the highest yield of ammonia. Accordingly, as shown in Fig. 4c, the as-prepared SM-MoS2-x catalyst exhibits the maximum value of NH3 yield (gas purging rate = 20 mL min−1) of 17.2 μg h−1mgcata −1 at −0.2 V vs. RHE with a competitive Faradaic efficiency of 24.7 % (Fig. 4d, Table S1).

In order to confirm the source of nitrogen for NH3 production, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy has also been employed [53]. Notably, the 15N isotopic labeling experiments results (a doublet pattern with the coupling constant of J N–H = 73 Hz) in Fig. 4e indicated the generation of 15NH4 +. Furthermore, the obtained NH3 production rate and the corresponding FE by using 15N2-purged electrolyte are comparable to those by using 14N2 (Figs. S10, 11), and it demonstrates clearly that the detected NH3 is attributed to the electroreduction of N2 [53]. Moreover, control experiments are carried out by comparing the NRR electrolysis at different experimental conditions according to the recent protocols (Figs. 4f, S12) [41]. In a 22 h NRR stability test of the as-prepared SM-MoS2-x at a potential of -0.2 V vs. RHE, merely a tiny decrease in current density can be observed (Fig. S15). The cycle tests show stable ammonia yied rate and FE (Fig. S16), indicating the fine durability of the sub-monolayer MoS2-x catalysts for NRR electrocatalysis. Moreover, the XRD and TEM results of SM-MoS2-x after the stability test demenstrate the structural stability of the as-designed catalyst (Figs. S17, 18). Notably, after the stability test, N2H4 is not detected in the obtained electrolyte, indicating the as-constructed catalyst has good selectivity for NH3 synthesis (Fig. S19) [54]. Notably, the NH3 yield rate of the e-NRR using as-prepared SM-MoS2-x catalyst is obviously higher than that of using pristine MoS2 nanosheets (Fig. S20), indicating that the asymmetrical sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure can expedite the e-NRR. These results demonstrate that the generated NH3 is successfully obtained from the electroreduction of N2 by using SM-MoS2-x catalyst.

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are performed to understand the underlying mechanisms of the enhanced NRR activity in the SM-MoS2-x system. Firstly, the calculated density of states (DOS) in Fig. S21 shows that the SM-MoS2-x possesses a dramatical increased electron states close to the Feimi level and a narrower bandgap (0.2 eV) than that of the pristine MoS2 (1.60 eV), leading to more charge carriers and higher intrinsic conductivity [46]. These are strong evidences to demonstrate the partially relief of p-block of S to Mo on the S vacancy region. Usually, the three commonly proposed criteria for eligible NRR electrocatalysts are as follows: ⅰ) being able to facilitate the chemisorption and activation of N2 molecules; ⅱ) stabilizing *N2H; ⅲ) destabilizing *NHz(2 or 3) [8,9,20].

Based on the aforementioned criteria, the Gibbs free energies of plausible intermediates during NRR process are investigated. As shown in Fig. 5 a, at the first stage, the N2 molecule is adsorbed on the Mo hollow sites spontaneously with a tilted side-on adsorption configuration (Ⅰ→Ⅱ), resulting in a strong adsorption with Gibbs free energy of −0.42 eV (Ⅱ). The NN bond length has been strongly elongated from 1.10 Å (Ⅰ) in the gas phase to 1.27 Å (Ⅱ), implying that inert N2 is chemisorbed and activated by the Mo atoms in the S vacancy region (follwing the first criterion) [22,55]. Subsequently, the first H is added to the upper N atom (Ⅱ→Ⅲ) with a release of 0.1 eV free energy, leading to the further elongation of NN bond length to 1.35 Å (Ⅲ). Thus, the constructed SM-MoS2-x is feasible for stabilizing *N2H (following the second criterion). Besides, comparing with the end-on dinitrogen adsorption mode which need to overcome an energy barrier of 1.23 eV for the first hydrogenation of N2 (Fig. S22), the side-on adsorption of dinitrogen should be the predominant configuration.

Meanwhile, there are two branch routes for the addition of the second H to form *NNH2 (Ⅳ) or *NHNH, both are exothermic while the path to *NNH2 (Ⅳ) is more energetically favorable with NN bond length of 1.41 Å, and the calculated free energy of *NNH2 (Ⅳ) is 0.50 eV lower than that of *NHNH. The reaction step from the adsorbed *NNH2 to *NHNH2 (Ⅳ→Ⅴ) species is thermodynamically uphill with a free energy change of 0.56 eV. The adsorption of the H atom on the lower N atom break one Mo-N bond and elongate the NN bond length to 1.46 Å. The *NHNH2→*NH2NH2 (Ⅴ→Ⅵ) step is energy uphill with 0.49 eV free energy increase. Specially, the NN bond breaking step *NH2NH2→*NH2+*NH2 (Ⅵ→Ⅶ) is also exothermic with energy release of 0.67 eV, and the calculated energy barrier is only 0.18 eV. Additionally, our calculation shows that the release of N2H4 is uncompetitive with an energy barrier of 1.46 eV, corroborating well with the experimental data. Next, during the formation of NH3, the *NH2-*NH2→*NH2-*NH3 (Ⅶ→Ⅷ) and *NH2→*NH3 (Ⅸ→Ⅹ) steps are both exothermic and release 0.73 and 0.71 eV free energy, respectively.

Due to the high activity of the exposed Mo atoms, the rate-limiting step of the NRR on the SM-MoS2-x surface corresponds to the release of NH3, with activation barriers of 0.70 and 0.66 eV for the release of first and second NH3, respectively, which are much smaller than most of the currently reported results [14]. It should be noted that the migration of NH3 to the edge Mo atoms sites can further reduce the energy barrier for the release of NH3. The maximum energy barrier of the hopping of *NH3 on the sub-monolayer MoS2-x surface is only 0.58 eV (Fig. 5b). When the NH3 migrate to the edge Mo atoms sites, the release of NH3 become much easier, with an energy barrier only 0.2 eV (following the third criterion). Meanwhile, the generated NH3 can be easily dissolved in water, which can prompt the NH3 release from the catalyst. Thus, the free energy barrier referring to the electrochemical PCET of NRR is 0.56 eV, essentially [39]. On the basis of these calculated values, the biomimetic NRR electrocatalytic behavior of sub-monolayer MoS2-x is revealed, and the flexible active surface can bond nitrogen intermediates in a dynamic binding paradigm, by which the intermediates molecules can be adjusted into more stable configurations.

Besides, surpressing the competing HER by reducing the potential has been pursued in recent research [14,39]. It has been reported that the hydrogen (H*) adsorption free energies (ΔGH*) can be tuned very close to 0 when the S-vacancy concentration of the monolayer MoS2 lies between 9 %–19 %, suggesting single S-vacancy sites are more favorable for HER [51]. In contrast, with sufficient Mo exposed in the SM-MoS2-x, the ΔGH* reaches −0.53 eV. As a result, HER would be partially retarded, for the reason that the energy barriers for the adsorbed active H* to participate in the PCET steps are even lower than that for HER (Fig. 5b) [40].

While traditional cognitions of the dominant active centers in MoS2 catalysts are edge sites, the in-plane S-vacancies have recently been found to activate the basal plane dramatically to many catalytic reactions with unusual mechanisms. In this study, a peculiar sub-monolayer MoS2-x structure with large area of in-plane S-vacancies is created. Atomic resolution AC-STEM and computational simulations show the compressive strain in S vacancy regions, which increases the metallicity and further enriches the electron density around. Experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the large area of in-plane S-vacancies can tune their catalytic properties through adjusting their affinity to nitrogen intermediates, leading to the circumvention of the adsorption free energy scaling relationships in catalysis of N2 electroreduction with ultra-low overall energy barrier and overpotential. Notably, the migration of *NH3 on this active surface further facilitate the release of NH3. Besides, the relatively strong adsorption of H suppresses the HER and benefits the PCET for NRR. This well-established relationship between the geometric and electronic structure and the catalytic performance can help the understanding of distinct catalytic properties between 0D point S vacancies and 2D nano S vacancies, and paves the way towards the design of high-performance catalysts. It can be anticipated that the findings in this work may be expanded to other metallic-anion compound catalysts and other catalytic reactions in the near future.

Qun Xu and Wenzhuo Wu conceived the ideas, designed the experiments and co-wrote the manuscript. Qun Xu, Yu Jia, Jun Chen and Chuan Zhao supervised the entire project. Wenzhuo Wu performed the materials synthesis, characterization and performance experiments. Chunyao Niu and Pengfei Yan contributed to the DFT calculations and co-wrote the corresponding content. Feng Shi assisted with the materials synthesis. Jun Chen and Yu Jia assisted with data analysis and manuscript revision. Xinan Yang and Chunyan Ma contributed to the AC-STEM characterization experiments. Chuan Zhao and Muhammad Ibrar Ahmed contributed to the 15N isotopic labeling experiments.
